Michael Stack wrote:
> I haven't done the mental-decoding to figure how Heritrix arrived at 
> http://www.igsoc.org/symposia/www.igsoc.org 
> <http://www.igsoc.org/symposia/www.igsoc.org>, perhaps one of the other 
> lads have it at their fingertips, but here's where you'd start if you 
> wanted to have a go yourself: 
> http://crawler.archive.org/xref/org/archive/crawler/extractor/ExtractorHTML.html

It's quite common for the 'value' attributes of <input> (and <option>) 
elements to be relative URIs. Sometimes they are then used by Javascript 
in the page (which we cannot execute) to send the browser somewhere when 
the user selects/clicks; other times they are returned to the server 
which then redirects to the named URI.

So, when those values 'look like URIs' to us -- chiefly, by having 
internal '.' or '/' characters without internal spaces -- we try them as 
URIs. As Stack noted, we usually will risk 404s to avoid missing content 
that we couldn't discover otherwise.

- Gordon @ IA
